title: Can there be any good in the world if there is no evil? - Quora

response.answer_text: Approaching this question objectively: First some preliminary observations to consider: The question, as stated, presupposes these relative concepts, which humans variously refer to as “good” and “evil”.The concepts of “good” and “evil” are abstract, by definition, and how each is perceived is definitely not agreed upon by all humans. Cultures (like our own, which are deeply imbued with religious sentiment, from West to East) have long-held and deeply saturated beliefs about the concepts of “good” and “evil.” These tend to be more concrete in the minds of adherents than they actually are.The concepts of “good” and “evil” are typically considered polar opposites—in terms of “either good or evil”—but this is not actually the truth of the matter. Rather, it might be more true to propose that the concepts of “good” and “evil,” (assuming their existence) reside on opposite ends of a spectrum; thus the concept of relativity is introduced.Whether something is “good” or “evil” depends on how we perceive it. For example, some wholeheartedly believe that to consciously and premeditatively take the life of another human being in the context of capital punishment is essentially a good and just thing to do, whereas others see the same act as evil, equal to murder. The same is true of abortion; or consider even cannibalism, where another farflung culture’s beliefs are concerned, or otherwise where the impossible choice of one’s own life or death might be at hand. Other examples include war, or suicide (with or without assistance by a physician), or the killing of animals for sport (particularly those that are rare or endangered), or ‘mercy killing,’ ethnic cleansing, euthanasia—the list could go on and on, actually.Whereas we might like to believe that the definitions of “good” and/vs “evil” ought to be clear and simple, in reality they are not at all. So therein lies our most significant place to start, where answering this question is concerned.“Good” and “evil” (or “bad”) are words we learn as children. But what do we actually mean by them? Words are only signifiers, like avatars or icons, which point to and ‘stand for’ something else that we like to think we agree about, serving our ability to communicate. Thus I suggest that this is where one should start when proposing to answer the question presented here: “Can good exist without evil?”PS: Obviously there is another distinct context in which this question is being asked, that referring to the relative existence of “good” and “evil,” in the same context as that of others such as big and small, light and dark, tall and short, high and low, fast and slow, etc. Thus the question being asked is: Can our concept of “good” exist at all if we do not, at the same, hold a concept of “evil,” which we perceive to be relatively the opposite of “good”? (likewise, could our concept of ‘big’ exist without our having a relative concept of ‘small’? etc).I like this question. It is actually a very good one to ponder, given that so much of our daily life and strife as humans is directly related to our beliefs about “good” and “bad,” or “evil.” So, what might be your thoughts about what I’ve responded with here, so far? How might one actually go about answering the question? JH.Boise

I see a lot of wery WEIRD arguments here. Like “without evil, things that are less good become the new evil…”. Sophistry, smoke, mirrors and logical fallacies, mates! Allow me to dismantle it for you. Imagine yourself petting a dog. The dog is happy and wags its tail. You’re also happy. That is a simple moment of good.  Does this moment need evil, like murder and ass cancer, to be possible?Does this moment become evil the minute it somehow becomes impossible to beat the dog instead?Is this moment evil in comparison with taking your kids to Disneyland?No. None of the above is true. The only argument you could make is that petting the dog can only exist if an opposite state - not petting the dog - is possible, and that state is “evil”. Indeed, that is the crux of all “good requires evil” arguments I’ve heard: that evil is the absence of good. To which I once again reply: hogwash! There’s a vast spectrum of neutral and uncomfortable states that cannot be called evil - yet can be improved. Unfulfilled needs only become “evil” in extreme circmstances. Starvation in practice does not happen in developed countries. The people reading this will never experience starvation. We will all experience mild hunger. But mild hunger is not evil. Hunger does not become evil if it is no longer possible to starve. Heck, people often do cleanses or diets and intentionally put themselves through the discomfort of hunger. TLDR There is a vast spectrum of situations where good (or more good) is possible without any evil being present - whether the evil is factual or potential.

We generally consider Evil to be the opposite of Good. But for our purposes here, let’s simply consider it an alternative. That is, they’re still mutually exclusive, but there may be other possible things to be. Now let’s consider something else that a thing could be: salty. Salty means “having salt or the flavor of salt.” So, salty is something that a food could be. Food could also be bitter, or sweet, or sour. But let’s say that humans never developed the senses of bitter or sweet or sour. Let’s say that all we could detect was salt. Does that mean that “salty” no longer exists? Since it’s all we understand, we wouldn’t call it salty, since there is nothing else it could be. We may not even recognize that there’s a possibility for food to be anything other than salty. But none of that changes the fact that the food has (the flavor of) salt. The food is salty, regardless of our perception. Of course, Good and Evil are less quantifiable concepts, but the point is the same. Without Evil, we may not recognize Good, and we likely would not have a name for it, since that’s all there is. But that wouldn’t change the fact that Good would still exist.

Sure, technically. The word “good” is simply a label we choose to put onto certain things. Good does not actually exist in itself. It’s an abstract concept. Things may be labeled good. Obviously you don’t need the label “evil.” It sort of seems a bit cockeyed to have a label “good” and not a label “evil,” but humans do cockeyed things every day. Sometimes we elect a loony psychopathic thug to national office, so go figure. But- but- but don’t you have some sort of objective state of being, called “good,” and isn’t it the exact antithesis of an objective state of being, called“evil?” Uh, no. Here’s why. “Good” is a label we use for things we choose to call good. However, I just spouted nonsense. “WE” don’t label something good or evil. You may do it, and I may do it, and Joe Rosenschmuck across the street may do it, and guess what? Our three definitions of good and of evil will be three different things. It might be that they are very, very similar, but they are different. Each of us has different experiences, different expectations, maybe even some off-the-wall biases that skew our perceptions. Anyway, no, there is no objective state of being called evil or good. We simply apply the labels, and for each of us, those labels mean just what we decide they mean, crazy thought that may sound. So since “good” is merely a label, then sure, you can have “good” and not have evil — technically. Since part of the definition of both terms usually relates directly to the other, however, it might be hard to pull that off. Am I getting at what you are trying to find out at all?

I recall a phrase I read/heard from somewhere: "If there is no evil in this world, then the good will become evil." Or something like that. When I first read/heard it, I felt that sentence didn't quite make sense: how can good people become evil once evil is removed? But then, if one were to look at good and evil as on a scale from left to right with evil being on the left, and good being on the right end, and you remove evil from the scale, what would we have left? We would have the remaining good on a shorter scale from left to right, with the good on the left being the "lesser good". Might this lesser good become the "new evil"? Of course, this is assuming that good and evil exist on the same scale (judged upon the same criterion), and that there is no zero point *separating the positive from the negative. My example aside, I think good can exist without evil. If we could remove all the darkness and evil from all our minds and hearts, the world would be a much, much better place to live. An ideal world based on love and mutual respect for one another. But some might argue that good and bad can be relative, e.g. A good bottle of wine can only be called "good" based on how much better it is compared to bad-tasting wine. But then this should only be applicable to some situations, and not for good and evil in the moral sense. In this case, an act of kindness or compassion can be considered good on its own, without comparing it something malicious. So long story short, I do think good can exist without evil, but the question is: can evil be removed from this world?

What’s the baseline of declaring the following: One is better than the other.There are giants in that mountain.I am rich.You are lucky.I am taller than you.We can declare the existence of one truth (or fact, as the case maybe) due to the existence of the other. The absence of evil disproves the existence of good or attribution to it — and in such case, good can never be proven that it exists in the first place. Our “physical universe” as governed by classical laws of physics displays the truth about Einstein’s Theory of Relativity. Why do we claim that our time on earth runs faster than when we are close to the event horizon of a black hole? Because we have a local experience and can measure (or compare) that time is relative. Perhaps in “another universe” not governed by classical physics (as we know it here) — there exist a “singular and absolute existence” which we may call as “good without evil”.

A sound is a good thing, but a musical note is better. A musical note is good, but a chord is better, A chord is good, but a tune is better. A tune is good, but a musical theme is better. A musical theme is good, but a symphony is better. And so on. Goodness is a constructive concept. There is no a priori limit to the degree in which phenomena can be good. And the degree of goodness can be determined without any reference to evil. The good can exist without evil. The reverse is not true. Evil is a corruption of the good, and cannot exist independently of it. The notion that evil is the opposite of the good is dangerous, for it leads people to try to achieve the good by means of the elimination of evil. This doesn’t work, because it does not help to achieve higher levels of goodness. A tune, removed of evil, will still be a tune and not a theme. Not only do attempts to achieve good by eliminating evil not work, they generally result in less good. For the energy we apply in order to eliminate evil cannot be used to achieve the good. Even worse, the elimination of one evil often leads to - or even requires - other evils. Jesus of Nazareth taught his followers not to resist evil, but to devote their energy to achieving the good. The United States, as a professedly Christian country, should apply his teaching, and stop the un-Christian and evil practice of imprisoning large parts of its population. Maybe it will then truly become the good society that it aims to be.

Good and evil are predicated on the intent of the actor.  An event itself is neither good nor evil, it simply is.  The intent behind the action (if indeed there is any) would be considered good or evil.  A school full of children has a gas line rupture and explode, burning everyone inside to death.  There was no evil done, although that makes it no less tragic.  If a person purposely set fire to the school with the intent to burn everyone inside, that act would be evil, whether or not anyone actually burned.  Then, if a teacher ran back into the burning building with the intent to save people, that act would be good, because the intent was good.  If a person ran back into the building to make sure the doors and windows were all locked so that no one could escape, even if he did not find any doors or windows to lock before once again fleeing the building, the act would be evil, even though the action and the result were the same as when the teacher ran back to save students and found no one, thereby escaping the building empty-handed. Good and evil are not relative to one another.  There can be good in the world without the presence of evil to which it can be compared, and vice versa.  The intent, if any, would be absolute, and that is where one would find good or evil or both.

Good and Evil are subjective.  They are two sides to the same object.  If you have a front, you have to have a back. If we were to eliminate everything that was "evil" from the world, people would then begin to discriminate between things that were "really" good, and things that were "not so" good.  And... those things that weren't really all that good, but definitely not evil before, would become the new evil. That's the thing about opposites.  You have to have both, if you want to be able to distinguish between them.  Otherwise, if there is only one, there would be no concept of the other.  Good would be meaningless if everything was "good".  If everything was "good"... then everything would just be.  It wouldn't be good. So yes.  Good, which is a comparative state, cannot exist without something to compare it to.

The quick response would likely be to say "no" based on the assumption that good and evil are merely two counterbalancing forces; or perhaps two sides of the same thing. I believe that that assumption would likely be wrong. Stealing something from a hotel room is wrong or evil. But millions of people stay in hotels every day; andl leave without stealing anything, it is certainly a good thing, but it seems a stretch to hold as a virtue opposite of stealing, simply because it is what is expected of a human. A person can be charitable and quick to lend a helping hand - a clear virtue. On the hand many people are not that generous, without being labeled evil. I believe that good and evil stand on their own, and in any given period a community may have an abundance of one and sparcity of another. On occasion they may balance each other out, but that is an incidental finding and not because good and evil must do so. A given society's highest achievement is an eradication of evil and a voluntary adoption of good; and that is also the teaching of most religions.

Sure.  A coworker brought zucchini bread in to the office today.  That was good.  Would it have been evil if she'd decided that we didn't really need any zucchini bread?  That seems a pretty harsh judgment.  It takes a pretty arbitrary and unintuitive definition of evil for that to happen. But I'm not sure how much we've learned from this observation.  "Good" and "evil" are ill-defined categories, with vast amounts of overlap, subject to both point of view and hard-to-measure notions like "intention" and "long-term ramifications".   I suppose it shows that evil and good aren't equal and opposite.  The world is not a zero-sum game.  We can do things to make it better, and we can do things to make it worse.  It's not necessary for something to be able to be made worse in order to make it better.  That seems pretty obvious to me, and makes me wonder why one would even want to ask the question.

(perhaps this should be a comment but it is probably more borderline answer) I'm not all that sure that the original question is structured in a way that makes an answer to this either easy or conceivable. couple of points/questions:  are we supposing a system of opposites? if so, is good contra evil? or does it make more sense to say good contra bad? the reason i ask is that if one were to take the perspective as found in say Nietzsche's Genealogy of Morals, then the question would make little sense.are we speaking of the ideas of good or evil or the linguistics that surround their conceptualization + perhaps form the mindset of an individual?are we speaking in a universal sense or merely occidental? language has a lot to do with perception + formulation of these notions.in any event, the logical/rational/scientific side of me says that if there were not an agent + it's opposite/contrast then all would be the same + no one would know the difference + it would all be desultory words attached to the same entity/notion. in the current way of thinking/living, i would find it difficult to conceive of good without an opposite to reflect upon (a coefficient of force).

Absolutely. Light exists, and the absence of light or less light is referred to as darkness or “dark”. But darkness is not a counter-force, there is no carrier particle or wave or negative energy at work. Heat exists, and the absence of it is referred to as cold. But there is no such force as negative heat. When it is cold out, or even if there was an absolute zero of heat, that isn’t a different and opposing force at work. That is just less or no heat. People can be very good, more good, less good, not very good at all, or totally immoral. But there is no counter-force, no negative good. Evil is a myth. Read more about that here: Daniel Albert's answer to Why do people willingly do evil when they are well aware that it is evil?

It all depends on ones definitions of good and bad (evil). Good can be universally recognized as a conscious intent to promote the well-being of others, and evil as a conscious intent to maliciously harm others. Although they may be opposites, does one truly need to exist for the other to exist? Good can exist without evil, and vice versa, evil can exist without good. Orchestrating a genocidal famine does not need altruism to exist in order to be implemented, nor does the intent of freely giving to the less fortunate need intentional malice to exist to place them into such destitution. And where does that put indifference or neutrality? Simply by not killing people, does that mean you're good? Simply by minding your own business and not going door to door making sure your neighbor is safe and secure, does that mean you're evil?

Yes, of course. Good actions and good sentiments will still exist even if evils have been controlled, diminished, and set into remission. Good and evil will always exist as existential concepts, and it’s true that the existential concept of good means that an existential concept of evil also must exist. But evil does not have to be active in the world in order for there to be good. If goodness is everywhere, then it just means that evil will have been placed into remission. For instance, if the world is safe and secure, then you can still show affection to others, fall in love, etc. etc. and do everything else good and positive.
